{"blocks":[{"key":"dre7d","text":"For microscopes used for colocalization experiments, it is recommended to run this protocol at least after installation and maintenance. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"93vm6","text":"Beads Selection","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4eolq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"185jq","text":"Different bead sizes can be used to assess co-registration accuracy in microscopy systems. Multi-color TetraSpeck beads of sizes 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 4 µm are commercially available. We evaluated the performance of Tetraspeck 0.2, 1, and 4 µm beads side by side across 12 microscopes, with testing conducted by 11 members of the Quarep-LiMi WG4. Data analysis was performed using MetroloJ_QC (version 1.3.1.2), a plugin for Fiji/ImageJ software. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7tokm","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ot7p","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4rac2","text":"The green channel was used as the reference to determine the distance to the far-red (Ch0), red (Ch1), and blue (Ch3) channels. Our results indicate that 1 and 4 µm TetraSpeck beads have comparable performance, providing consistent measurements in the XY and Z-axis (Figures 3, 4, and 5). In contrast, Tetraspeck 0.200 µm beads exhibit higher variability and dispersion in measurements across all channels, particularly along the Z-axis (Figures 3B, 4B, and 5B), likely due to their lower achievable signal levels compared to the larger bead sizes. Additionally, 0.2 µm beads may be more prone to forming clumps that can be difficult to identify during image acquisition. ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":267,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3n2ur","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8qsp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8bg7m","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b47ju","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"56fbl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4um7n","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6seks","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ak4n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4o83o","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3i21q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1c5qu","text":"For the 0.2 µm beads, two different sampling metrics were tested: 0.016 x 0.016 x 0.040 µm and 0.070 x 0.070 x 0.200 µm (Figures 6, 7, and 8). The results showed that smaller voxel sizes yield more precise and robust distance measurements to the reference channel. The SBR was comparable between the two voxel sizes, indicating that the primary difference was in the number of voxels and, consequently, the number of photons.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":121,"length":12},{"style":"bold","offset":134,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5808n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4rgsh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1dtqd","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"97u9e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"78s4n","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":4,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"f6ekn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c5sud","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":5,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"emq7q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"hnq5","text":"The co-registration distance relative to the microscope’s theoretical resolution was calculated for all bead sizes. As shown in Figures 9A, 9B, and 9C, for the 4 µm and 1 µm beads, the ratios are below the system’s theoretical resolution, indicating that they are performing correctly with respect to co-registration. For the 0.2 µm beads, the data show greater dispersion; however, the majority of the analyzed beads fall within the reference ratio of 1. The same data are also represented in Figure 9D, where the distance ratio between the blue–green (B–G) channel and the red–green (G–R) channel is shown for all beads, and the Figure 9E, where the distance ratio between the Far red–green (G-FR) channel and the red–green (G–R) channel is shown for all beads. The green region indicates values with acceptable co-registration. In this representation, the beads with a ratio greater than 1 are easy to track, and it becomes clearer that the 0.2 µm beads are indeed problematic when analyzing the blue–green and the far red-green distances.  \n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":136,"length":2},{"style":"bold","offset":140,"length":2},{"style":"bold","offset":148,"length":2},{"style":"bold","offset":501,"length":2},{"style":"bold","offset":638,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eaeo2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b48nl","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":6,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1no57","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e6gf7","text":"Despite the higher standard deviation observed with the Tetraspeck 0.2 µm beads, the average distances calculated to the reference channel were similar across all three bead sizes and the two voxel sizes.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ektog","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cr864","text":"Several parameters influence the ability to localize a bead, including its size, brightness, and the microscope's point spread function (PSF). The higher standard deviation observed with Tetraspeck 0.2 µm beads may result from their relatively weak fluorescence signal, as they contain fewer fluorescent molecules, which can lead to a low SBR and makes localization analysis more challenging. In contrast, due to their larger volume, 1 and 4 µm beads produce stronger fluorescence signals that improve the SBR, facilitating more precise localization analysis.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ek2nh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"10djd","text":"Although smaller beads, such as the Tetraspeck 0.2 µm, enable higher localization precision, we recommend using Tetraspeck 1 µm beads for routine co-registration analysis, as they yield higher SBR and provide more stable and reliable results, as our findings indicate. Therefore, 1 µm beads are better suited for routinely assessing the co-registration performance of microscopy systems, particularly in high-resolution systems where strong signal intensity is crucial, such as confocal laser scanning microscopes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8anbv","text":"Of note, if localization precision is a key factor for a specific application, smaller diameter beads, such as the Tetraspeck 0.2 µm beads, should be used, guaranteeing that a sufficiently high SNR can be achieved. If a system is equipped only with low magnification objectives, the Tetraspeck 4 µm would be preferable.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6bmfd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9911s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"86j1h","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":7,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3hbu5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"67vu8","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":8,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3uj2a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9vhs3","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"190oc","text":" MetroloJ_QC gitHub: https://github.com/MontpellierRessourcesImagerie/MetroloJ_QC)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":21,"length":60}],"entityRanges":[{"key":9,"offset":21,"length":60}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"97E040D1BBF811F094050A58A9FEAC02","height":230,"id":658374,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"4sbbl\",\"text\":\"Figure 3: Lateral (XY) and axial (Z) distances were measured between far-red and green channels (Ch0) in µm on different bead sizes (4, 1, and 0.2 µm). Voxels are 0.070 x 0.070 x 0.200 µm. Measurements have been made by 11 WG04 Quarep members on more than 12 microscopes.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":9}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Fig_Ch0.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/vsmhbq5gf.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/wc8gbq5gf.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/wc8fbq5gf.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"C9C15394BBF811F0BFFC0A58A9FEAC02","height":230,"id":658378,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"2r78e\",\"text\":\"Figure 4: Lateral (XY) and axial (Z) distances were measured between red and green channels (Ch1) in µm on different bead sizes (4, 1, and 0.2 µm). Voxels are 0.070 x 0.070 x 0.200 µm. Measurements have been made by 11 WG04 Quarep members on more than 12 microscopes.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":9}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Fig_Ch1.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/vsmjbq5gf.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/wc8kbq5gf.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/wc8jbq5gf.webp","width":550}},"2":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"EF8C7D95BBF811F0BFFC0A58A9FEAC02","height":230,"id":658380,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"5cd8h\",\"text\":\"Figure 5: Lateral (XY) and axial (Z) distances were measured between blue and green channels (Ch3) in µm on different bead sizes (4, 1, and 0.2 µm). Voxels are 0.070 x 0.070 x 0.200 µm. {"blocks":[{"key":"9j4jt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e9ad2","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7j6is","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"result","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bcbl","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1rg69","text":" ","type":"atomic"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6lqg","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"alt":"","guid":"14AD3BE7CC3111EFA8120A58A9FEAC02","height":243,"id":658388,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"53ig9\",\"text\":\"Figure 2: Visual representation and quantification of different co-registration accuracy outcomes. Starting with a real dataset exhibiting an optimal level of co-registration (A), different levels of mis-registration in B and C were simulated by purposefully shifting one channel image of the bead relative to the other. Panel (A) shows an optimal co-registration of a single bead imaged in the middle of the FOV, characterized by precise alignment across all spatial axes (X, Y, Z). Panel (B) represents a minor co-registration shift along the X-axis (0.179 µm), characterized by a slight misalignment that may require minor adjustments or post-acquisition image processing to correct. Panel (C) illustrates a severe mis-registration shift along the Z-axis (0.599 µm), marked by a significant focal displacement between these channels. Under such conditions, steps must be taken to account for this mis-registration if conducting any co-localization or channel intensity ratiometric analyses either by system realignment, post-acquisition image registration correction, or simply excluding the region of the FOV where this bead resides for any of these types of analyses. The analysis of these real and simulated datasets was performed using MetroloJ_QC (version 1.3.1.1).\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":9},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":327,\"length\":3},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":490,\"length\":3},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":693,\"length\":3}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":"step-FF4CAB5DFDEB42BDA74DA8D0FF2E8B2D-nested-draft-e9ad2","original_name":"imagemrepresentativa_shiftsimulation.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/si5bbwxi7.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/wc8wbwxi7.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/wc8vbwxi7.webp","width":550},"mutability":"IMMUTABLE","type":"image"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"952p9","text":"If your images exhibit any misregistration, you can refer to the troubleshooting section for guidance.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d7rrf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2900t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dud52","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5e3rj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"20jet","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7b1c0","text":"Here are the main steps to follow if you are using MetroloJ_QC plugin (version 1.3.1.2) on ImageJ :","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65um3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"72dt6","text":"Launch ImageJ (or Fiji) and open the MetroloJ_QC toolbar (Plugins \u003e MetroloJ_QC)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d82nm","text":"Open your 3D multichannel stack (single 1 µm bead, 4 channels)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5apno","text":"Click on the Co-registration Tool icon","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2tkep","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"meh3","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8ut37","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7asno","text":"Before launching the MetroloJ_QC plugin, check the noise in the different channels. If needed, apply a median filter (radius 2-3) and a Substract background (radius 50). Noise is more prone to be seen in the blue channel.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6ct1u","text":"In the Microscope Acquisition Parameters: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3d93o","text":"Choose the microscope type (CLSM), the objective specification, the pinhole size, and the excitation wavelengths.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b5abf","text":"In the Bead Detection Options: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fhgo6","text":"Choose a thresholding method (\"Minimum\" is advised for noisy images);","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"21ue6","text":"Select “Centroid” as the center detection method;","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eab2n","text":"Enable “Discard bead if more than one particle is thresholded\". Set the background annulus size (for signal-to-background calculation);","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fkbn5","text":"Return to the main window, select \"PDF report\" and \"Excel spreadsheet\" in the \"File Save Options\", and run the analysis.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"en4je","text":"The tool will compute three useful metrics : ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bf19n","text":"Shifts in X, Y, Z between all channel pairs: These represent the pixel distances between the bead centers in each channel pair along the X, Y, and Z axes. They quantify how misaligned the channels are in each spatial dimension.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":137,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3cr8q","text":"Center-to-center distances: This refers to the 3D Euclidean distance between the centers of beads in two different channels. It combines the X, Y, and Z shifts into a single value and is calculated as:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bdiaq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4koq6","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"tex_formula","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"formula":"\\text{Distance} = \\sqrt{(x_2 - x_1)^2 + (y_2 - y_1)^2 + (z_2 - z_1)^2}","guid":"","id":0}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"e5qsf","text":"Profile view images (XY, XZ, YZ) and outlines of the thresholded bead will be shown for visual inspection.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"88r5d","text":"Distance ratios relative to the reference resolution : This is the ratio of the measured center-to-center distance to the theoretical resolution of the microscope in the angle of the shift. \nIt helps assess how significant the shift is relative to the system’s resolution.\nA ratio \u003c 1 indicates acceptable co-registration; a ratio \u003e 1 suggests potential misalignment beyond the system’s resolving capability ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":67,"length":47},{"style":"bold","offset":134,"length":10},{"style":"bold","offset":275,"length":10},{"style":"bold","offset":323,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6t9ac","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4jk6g","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"align":"","authors":"Faklaris O, Bancel-Vallée L, Dauphin A, Monterroso B, Frère P, Geny D, Manoliu T, de Rossi S, Cordelières FP, Schapman D, Nitschke R, Cau J, Guilbert T","can_edit":true,"created_on":"","date":1667779200,"doi":"https://doi.org/10.1083/jcb.202107093","guid":"EE628FBACE0746DDA51730ACCA44184F","id":0,"journal":"","protocol_guid":"","protocol_id":0,"title":"Quality assessment in light microscopy for routine use through simple tools and robust metrics."}}}}

title: Ensuring accurate co-registration measurement for quality control of Single Point Confocal Laser Scanning Microscopes - V1
title_html: Ensuring accurate co-registration measurement for quality control of Single Point Confocal Laser Scanning Microscopes - V1

troubleshooting_items.problem: Objective Lens Chromatic Aberrations (the user can address)
troubleshooting_items.solution: Carefully check objective specifications to minimize color-dependent focal shifts. If possible, choose an apochromatic version of the objective to minimize chromatic aberrations.

troubleshooting_items.problem: Immersion Medium (Oil, Water, or Air) (the user can address)
troubleshooting_items.solution: Ensure that the medium is clear, has a correct refractive index and Abbe number, and is not out of date to avoid focal shifts, chromatic aberrations, or wavefront aberrations (like spherical aberration).
Clean your objective properly. Chromatic aberrations are often caused by dirt films on objectives.

troubleshooting_items.problem: Objective Collar Adjustment (if present) (the user can address)
troubleshooting_items.solution: Properly set for the correct coverslip thickness, medium, and temperature.

troubleshooting_items.problem: DIC Slider Positioning (the user can address)
troubleshooting_items.solution: Ensure the Differential Interference Contrast (DIC) slider is fully retracted or void when using the confocal mode to avoid beam path deviations.

troubleshooting_items.problem: Dichroic Mirrors and Beam Splitters (the user can address)
troubleshooting_items.solution: Ensure correct selection and consistent use across the different channel acquisitions to prevent spectral shifts between channels. Misaligned or mismatched dichroics can cause color registration errors.

troubleshooting_items.problem: Laser Beam Injection Alignment (need manufacturer assistance)
troubleshooting_items.solution: Verify precise beam alignment to prevent excitation shifts between channels.

troubleshooting_items.problem: Collimation of Laser Beams (need manufacturer assistance)
troubleshooting_items.solution: Ensure correct collimation for a consistent focal plane positioning across wavelengths. A 405 nm laser will often focus at a different position than blue, green, or red lasers. In most confocal scanning microscopes, the 405 nm laser path can be adjusted independently of the other lasers.

troubleshooting_items.problem: Galvanometric or Resonant Scanner Alignment (need manufacturer assistance)
troubleshooting_items.solution: Regularly calibrate scanners to prevent spatial drift between channels.
